children: A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for an 8-month history of malaise, fatigue, and subjective fever, as well as the recent onset of bilateral upper arm claudication.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Takayasu arteritis (TA). TA causes inflammation of the large vessels, most commonly the aorta, followed by the subclavian, common carotid, and renal arteries; the pulmonary arteries may also be involved. This patient's
demonstrates high-grade stenosis of the proximal right subclavian artery (
) as well as the left subclavian artery just below the origin of the left vertebral artery (

). Incidentally noted is anatomic variation with a common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and the left common carotid artery. TA manifestations include carotidynia, limb claudication, reduced pulses, bruits, and blood pressure discrepancies between the arms.
